thread.title: Tiger Kingdom tourists get close to UNCHAINED tigers on Phuket Island in Thailand
thread.title_full: Tiger Kingdom tourists get close to UNCHAINED tigers on Phuket Island in Thailand | Daily Mail Online

author: Georgia Diebelius For Mailonline
title: Tiger Kingdom tourists get close to UNCHAINED tigers on Phuket Island in Thailand
text:
3
View
comments
These astonishing pictures show families posing alongside - and stroking - unchained tigers at a zoo in Thailand.
Groups of tourists - with toddler children - can be seen climbing into the enclosures with the big cats at Tiger Kingdom on Phuket Island in Thailand.
The tigers are the Indochinese variety - which has seen a 70 per cent drop in population in just over a decade - and appear to be relaxed with the visitors.
Scroll down for video
A man and two children can be seen posing alongside a young Indochinese tiger cub at the zoo on Phuket Island in Thailand
Tourists can enter the animals enclosure and hire a professional photographer for a day to take their pictures with the rare tigers
Some tourists even choose to lay down beside the animal - of which there are only 350 left in the world - for their photograph

Hundreds of visitors a day visit the tiger zoo to touch the animals - which have been raised by trainers in Phuket since they were born.

On its website, Tiger Kingdom warns that although the tigers are tamed, they are not drugged or tranquillised and are still wild animals - so must be treated with respect.
'Cheerful' cubs as young as two to four months can be played with by guests.
A family pose like animals inside a cage behind one of the zoo's smallest Indochinese tigers for their souvenir photograph
Hundreds of visitors a day, including young children and families, visit the tiger zoo to touch and pose with the 'wild' animals in Thailand
Tourists are allowed to touch the animals, which range from ages two to 36 months, for as little as £14 per person.
Although Indochinese tigers have an average life span of 15 years - the Tiger Kingdom in Phuket only offers the petting service with tigers up to the age of three.
World leading nature conservation, World Wide Fund for Nature, state that only six countries - Thailand, Cambodia, China, Lao PDR, Myanmar and Vietnam - are now home to this subspecies.
All of the tigers at the private zoo have been raised by trainers in Phuket since they were born to ensure the safety of visitors
On their website, Tiger Kingdom warn that although the tigers are tamed, they must be treated with respect as they are still 'wild' at heart
